docs.title: Action Tree Fundamentals
docs.text: Action trees in .uri are essential for defining the interaction logic between the player and NPCs or objects, as well as determining NPC behavior within the game world. These trees are used to control everything from simple dialogues to complex behavior sequences, including 1-on-1 interactions and managing both local and global states at the NPC and tree level.

docs.title: Action Concept
docs.text:
The action is the most fundamental aspect of the tree, representing its nodes. It is a basic unit of behavior that is executed and does something in its context. Actions allow you to create dialogues, movements, state changes, calculations, and any other behavior you want to implement in the game. Each action can have a set of parameters that define what it does.

Actions can be used for interactions, behavior, or both. When an action is executed, the next action is executed unless the tree ends. It is the action itself that affects the flow of actions that follow—it can execute its first child action or its second, based on its result, which can be 1, 2, 3...

docs.title: Action Structure
docs.text:
An action consists of:

  • The action name: This is the action identifier and determines what type of behavior will be executed (e.g., say, ask, go).
  • Parameters: These are the data or additional information the action needs to execute (e.g., the message an NPC should say, the options for a question, the movement coordinates).
  • Results: Some actions return a numeric result that can be used to control the flow of the action tree (e.g., in the case of a question, the user's response determines the result: if they choose the first option, the result is one; if they choose the second, the result is two, and so on).

docs.title: say "Welcome to the world of .uri"
docs.text:
In this example, say is the action that indicates the NPC should display a message, and "Welcome to the world of .uri" is the parameter that contains the message.

ask "Onion in your tortilla or without?" "With onion" "Without onion" tell "So, with onion..." tell "So, without onion..."

In this other example, ask is an action that allows the user to choose within an interaction and conditions the conversation based on their choice. For instance, if the user chooses "With onion," the result of this action is 1, so the NPC will say the first of its next actions, "So, with onion."

docs.title: States and Variables
docs.text:
In .uri, both states and variables play a crucial role in managing NPC logic and interactions within the game. Variables are data containers that store information and can be either local or global. A local variable exists only for a single execution of the tree, and when it ends, it is erased. For example, if a player inputs their name in a dialogue, it could be stored in a local variable called player_name. This variable would only exist for that player until the actions in the tree end. On the other hand, a global variable is available even after the entire tree execution, and its value is shared and accessible at any time until the server is restarted. This is useful for data that must remain consistent across the game, such as a counter tracking how many times an NPC has been interacted with.

States, meanwhile, describe the current condition or behavior of an NPC and can also be local or global. A local state reflects the NPC's relationship with a specific player; for instance, a local state could indicate whether an NPC is following the player who activated it. This state is exclusive to that interaction. A global state, in contrast, affects how the NPC behaves with all players, such as if the NPC is in patrol or rest mode, and is visible and consistent for all users in the game. These states persist even if the server restarts.

Example: If an NPC has a global state of patrolling and a player interacts with it, it might activate a local state of following, causing the NPC to follow only that player. At the same time, other interactions would not affect its global patrol state. Additionally, the player's name could be stored in a local variable to personalize future interactions with that NPC during the same session. This differentiated use of states and variables allows for great flexibility and control in programming dynamic and specific behaviors in .uri.

docs.title: Example of a Local Variable
docs.text:
ask color "Tell me your favorite color:" "Enter the color..." "Blue" 20 tell "So, your favorite color is $color"

In this example: 1. The ask action stores the color the player inputs in the local variable color. 2. Then, the say action uses this local variable to personalize the NPC's dialogue.

docs.title: Example of a Global Variable
docs.text:
// This first line increments the counter by 1, or sets it to 0 and adds 1 if it's the first time. set mission_counter {$mission_counter or 0 + 1} // This line checks if it's already 10, and if so, the result of the action is 1. if {$mission_counter == 10} tell "We have completed $mission_counter missions." tell "We're not at 10 yet. We're at $mission_counter."

In this example: 1. The set action stores a global variable mission_counter and increments it. 2. Then, the if action checks if the counter has reached 10. 3. Finally, the NPC uses say to inform the player how the counter is progressing.

docs.title: Types of Action Trees
docs.text: There are two main types of action trees in .uri: interaction trees and behavior trees. While both function similarly, they have key differences that make them suitable for different purposes in the game.

docs.title: Interaction Tree
docs.text:
An interaction tree is a type of action tree that is executed when a player directly interacts with an NPC or object. This tree defines what happens when the player talks to the NPC, allowing for a series of chained actions related to the player. Interaction trees have default variables such as the player being spoken to as "player" and the NPC's name as "name."

Example:

Imagine a player talking to an NPC named Gustavo. Upon starting the conversation, the interaction tree might define the following sequence:

  1. Action Say: The NPC says: "Hi, my name is Gustavo."
  2. Action Ask: The NPC asks: "Are you from here?"
  3. Response 1: If the player answers "Yes" (returns 1), the NPC says: "Nice, I like you."
  4. Response 2: If the player answers "No" (returns 2), the NPC says: "Get out of here, we don't want you."

tell "Hi, my name is Gustavo." ask "Are you from here?" "Yes" "No" tell "Nice, I like you." tell "Get out of here, we don't want you."

Each action within the tree returns a result that can be used to determine the next action in the sequence, allowing for logical and dynamic interactions.

docs.title: Behavior Tree
docs.text:
A behavior tree, on the other hand, defines the actions that an NPC performs within the game world, independent of direct interaction with a player. This tree can control whether an NPC is patrolling, following a player, driving a vehicle, or performing any other autonomous action. Unlike the interaction tree, which runs once during an interaction, this tree runs on every tick (every few seconds). The behavior tree has the NPC's name as a variable called "name."

Example:

A behavior tree might define that an NPC patrols a specific area and changes its state to follow the player if it detects their presence.

  1. Action FindNearestPlayer: If a player is nearby, the NPC goes toward them.
  2. Response 1: The NPC is close to the player. Action Nothing: The NPC does nothing.
  3. Response 2: The NPC is moving toward the player. Action Nothing: The NPC does nothing.
  4. Response 3: No player is nearby. Action Wander: The NPC continues patrolling.

getClosestPlayer 15.0 3.0 nothing nothing wander -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 10 5 5

docs.title: Branch Locking
docs.text:
Behavior trees have a special feature that distinguishes them from interaction trees. Due to their nature of running every few seconds, an action might become useless if it doesn’t have time to finish before the next execution. To address this, there is the concept of locking the branch, meaning for a specific sequence of actions within the tree, you ensure the first action completes fully before allowing the next ones to proceed.

Example:

getClosestPlayer player; *surround $player 5 3 5 wait 10 playAnimation "anim@mp_player_intcelebrationmale@smoke_flick" "smoke_flick" playAnimation "anim@mp_player_intcelebrationmale@smoke_flick" "smoke_flick" playAnimation "mini@strip_club@lap_dance@ld_girl_a_exit" "ld_girl_a_exit_f"

In this example, we ensure that the NPC is circling around the player before waiting 10 seconds and then chaining the animations. If the NPC stops circling, it will recheck and resume circling.

docs.title: Using Tokens and Variables in Parameters
docs.text:
In .uri, tokens are used as parameters within the nodes of an action tree. A token can be a word, a number, or a variable. Variables can be used within text strings to be interpreted in real-time.

Example:

docs.title: tell "Hello, $player_name, welcome to the game."
docs.text: Here, $player_name is a variable that will be replaced in real-time by the previously stored player’s name.

docs.title: Arithmetic-Logical Expressions in .uri
docs.text:
In .uri, arithmetic-logical expressions allow for real-time calculations and evaluations within the code. These expressions are defined between curly braces {} and can include mathematical operations, logical comparisons, and the use of variables. The expressions behave similarly to Lua, but with minor differences, such as using != instead of ~= for inequality comparison.

Expressions can combine addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and more, allowing for dynamic logic within action trees.

docs.title: Arithmetic Expression Example
docs.text:
set result {2 + 3} tell "The result is $result."

In this example: 1. The expression {2 + 3} performs an addition, and the value 5 is stored in the variable result. 2. Then, the say action uses the $result variable to display the result in the dialogue.

docs.title: Example of strings with variables:
docs.text:
Strings can also be concatenated with other expressions within the curly braces {}, allowing for greater flexibility in messages and calculations involving text.

set player_name "Carlos" if {"Carlos" == $player_name} tell "Hello, $player_name, welcome to the game."

In this example: 1. The player_name variable is set to "Carlos". 2. A check is performed to see if two strings are equal. 3. The say action uses this variable within a string to create a dynamic message that greets the player by name.

docs.title: Using Variables in Expressions
docs.text:
You can use variables within expressions to make calculations dynamic. Variables must be preceded by $ to indicate that their current value is being used.

set points 50 set bonus {$points + 10} tell "You have earned $bonus experience points."

In this example: 1. A points variable is set to 50. 2. Then, the expression {$points + 10} adds 10 to the points variable, and the result (60) is stored in the bonus variable. 3. Finally, the NPC informs the player of their experience points using the $bonus variable.

docs.title: Logical Comparisons
docs.text:
.uri also allows for logical comparisons within expressions. You can compare values using operators such as >, <, >=, <=, == (equality), and != (inequality). These comparisons evaluate to true or false.

set current_health 30 set is_injured {$current_health < 50} tell "Are you injured?: $is_injured."

In this example: 1. The current_health variable has a value of 30. 2. The expression {$current_health < 50} evaluates whether the health is less than 50. Since the condition is true, the is_injured variable is set to true. 3. The NPC informs the player whether they are injured based on the expression's evaluation.

docs.title: Complex Expressions
docs.text:
Expressions in .uri also support combinations of arithmetic and logical operations in a single expression.

set health 100 set damage 30 set remaining_health {$health - $damage} set in_danger {$remaining_health <= 20} tell "You have $remaining_health health points left. Are you in danger?: $in_danger."

In this example: 1. The expression {$health - $damage} calculates the remaining health after receiving damage. 2. The expression {$remaining_health <= 20} evaluates whether the remaining health is less than or equal to 20, and if so, the in_danger variable is set to true. 3. The NPC informs the player of their remaining health and whether they are in danger.

docs.title: Support for Arithmetic and Logical Operations
docs.text:
.uri supports almost all common operations, including:

  • Addition: {a + b}
  • Subtraction: {a - b}
  • Multiplication: {a * b}
  • Division: {a / b}
  • Integer division: {a // b}
  • Comparisons: {a > b}, {a <= b}, {a == b}, {a != b}

These operations can be combined and nested to create complex logic that is evaluated in real-time during action execution.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Action trees in .uri offer a flexible and powerful structure for managing behavior and interactions in the game. Through actions, variables, states, and expressions, complex logic can be created that makes NPCs dynamically react and interact with players.

docs.title: Fundamentals of the .uri Language
docs.text: The .uri language is a simple programming language aimed at creating content for uri-core. Its main feature is that it is based on a tree structure, which allows hierarchical organization of the elements defined in the code. This is essential for designing a tree of possible interactions or behaviors for NPCs. Below, we explain the key concepts of the .uri language, its syntax, and its general operation.

docs.title: Node Concept
docs.text: In the .uri language, each line of code is primarily composed of words, phrases, or numbers (all referred to as tokens). The first word in the line is the most important as it defines something specific, and what follows is extra information that complements it. Each line can be understood as a node. Here we have several examples:

docs.title: Branch Concept
docs.text:
This tree is built as the code is written by relating all these nodes, where indentation (i.e., the number of tabs at the beginning of the line) determines the hierarchical relationship between the nodes, forming branches. The indentation of a new line must be less than, the same as, or one more than the immediately previous line. These are the 3 cases defined below.

  • Line indented the same as the previous one: They are considered siblings, meaning they are children of the same parent.

docs.title: Relation Example #1
docs.text:
Code:

name welcome
model a_m_y_hipster_02

Graphically:

  • Line indented one more than the previous one: It is considered a child of the immediately preceding line.

docs.title: Relation Example #2
docs.text:
Code:

    say "Welcome to .uri!"
        say "Where your dreams come true"

Graphically:

  • Line indented less than the previous one: It is a child of the same parent of another line that is equally indented.

docs.title: Relation Example #3
docs.text:
Code:

interaction
    say "Welcome to .uri!"
        say "Where your dreams come true"

behaviour

Graphically:

docs.title: Tree Concept
docs.text:
Once we combine all the examples, we can build a complete tree, which will be the basis for interpreting and creating our content. Let's see an example:

Code:

NPC

name welcome
model a_m_y_hipster_02
position -1056.683 4775.971 235.807 0.0

interaction
    say "Welcome to .uri!"
        say "Where your dreams come true"

behavior
    nothing

Graphically:

docs.title: Use of Semicolon to Control Hierarchy
docs.text:
To avoid overly indented or pyramid-like code, .uri allows the use of a semicolon (;) at the end of a line. This semicolon indicates that the next line, even if it has the same indentation, will be interpreted as a child of the previous line, not as its sibling. For example, this code is equivalent to the one above:

NPC

name welcome
model a_m_y_hipster_02
position -1056.683 4775.971 235.807 0.0

interaction
    say "Welcome to .uri!";
    say "Where your dreams come true"

behavior
    nothing

docs.title: Constructors
docs.text:
Constructors are fundamental elements in .uri. A constructor defines a new creation like an NPC, a quest, an item, etc. A constructor always starts with an uppercase word (for example, NPC), and its definition can include several attributes with different parameters that describe the characteristics or behaviors of this creation.

  • Attributes: Properties of the constructor that are defined on lines with the same indentation level as the constructor. For example, for an NPC, common attributes might include its position, name, model, etc.
  • Attribute parameters: Additional details that are defined following the attribute. For example, for the name, it would be welcome.

A single .uri file can contain multiple definitions of different constructors one after another, but an error interpreting the code of one constructor compromises the following definitions in that file.

A basic example of a constructor is what we have seen so far, defining an NPC:

NPC

name welcome
model a_m_y_hipster_02
position -1056.683 4775.971 235.807 0.0

interaction
    say "Welcome to .uri!";
    say "Where your dreams come true"

behavior
    nothing

docs.title: Respecting Indentation and Capitalization
docs.text: It is crucial to respect both the indentation and capitalization of tokens and constructors in .uri. The language is sensitive to these characteristics, meaning that a variation in capitalization or incorrect indentation can change the meaning of the code or even produce errors.

docs.title: Respect the required data for each field
docs.text: To avoid runtime errors, it is essential to follow the documentation when placing a value as a parameter.

docs.title: Comments, Spaces, and Blank Lines
docs.text: The .uri language is flexible regarding line separation. You can include blank lines where necessary to improve code readability without affecting its functionality. You can also separate tokens by spaces within a line for clarity, but remember that full phrases must be enclosed in quotes if they are to be treated as a single token. If you start a line with //, you add a comment that will not be processed, which can help clarify the intention of the code.

docs.title: Translation to Different Languages
docs.text:
The .uri language allows easy compatibility with translating any file into multiple languages. To implement this, there must be a file with the same name as the one to be translated but with the extension es.uriloc, where es is the language to be supported.

Everything that needs to be translated must appear in the .uri file as a single token without spaces in the form .example, where it always starts with a period followed by the ID assigned to the translation that will appear there. In the es.uriloc file, lines are added in the format where the ID comes first, followed by a colon, a space, and the string in quotes. In this case, it would be example: "This is a sample translation".

docs.title: Introduction to .uri
docs.text:
Welcome to .uri language. Here you will find all the necessary information to understand what it's about, comprehend its features, and learn how to unleash its full potential.

The .uri language was created with the goal of facilitating content creation for servers in a simple and accessible way. This language has been specifically designed to enable the construction of complex elements, such as NPCs, quests, and items, that can interact with each other in various enriching ways.

The structure of .uri is based on a tree-oriented paradigm, where each element created is represented as a branch within a tree, forming a variety of constructors that make up different entities in the game, like characters, quests, and more.

The .uri project originated in 2024, when the foundation known as uri-core was developed. This core solves a common problem in content development for servers: the high entry barrier due to the need for advanced programming knowledge.

Traditionally, adding high-quality content to a server required highly skilled personnel. However, .uri democratizes this process, lowering the skill level needed to participate in content creation.

Thanks to .uri, anyone with a basic interest can start creating their own NPCs, quests, and other interactive elements. This language allows you to easily define the interaction, unique characteristics, and even the behavior of these elements within the game world, making content creation more accessible and open to a larger community of users.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: To better illustrate how the .uri language works and how you can use it to create content on a server, let's examine a simple example. Imagine an NPC that interacts with players when they approach it. When the interaction begins, the NPC welcomes them to .uri and tells them that their dreams come true here. This is the example you see above in the gif, and below is the code that brings it to life.

docs.title: Example Code
docs.text:
NPC

name welcome
model a_m_y_hipster_02
position -1056.683 4775.971 235.807 0.0

interaction
    say "Welcome to .uri!"
    say "Where your dreams come true"

behaviour
    nothing

Although you might not fully understand it yet, you can get a sense of how easy it is to understand and see that the logic and behaviors of NPCs can be defined effortlessly.

docs.title: Development Environment
docs.text: To start working with the .uri language, it's essential to have a suitable development environment. Below, we explain how to set up Sublime Text so that you can develop efficiently, with full support for syntax, keyword highlighting, and autocomplete.

docs.title: Step 1: Install Sublime Text
docs.text:
1. Download the latest version of Sublime Text: Go to the official Sublime Text website and download the free community version: Download Sublime Text. Select the appropriate version for your operating system (Windows, macOS, Linux) and follow the installation instructions.

  2. Install Sublime Text: Once you’ve downloaded the installer, open it and follow the steps to install Sublime Text on your machine. After installation, open Sublime Text to verify that everything is working correctly.

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Sublime Text for .uri
docs.text:
1. To configure Sublime Text on Windows to work with the .uri language, you need to place four key files in the Packages/User folder, which you will find in the download below.

  2. First, open Sublime Text and, in the top menu bar, select Preferences and then Browse Packages.... This will open the file explorer in the Packages folder. Inside this folder, you will find a subfolder called User, which is where you should place all the files.

  3. The typical path for this folder on Windows is C:\Users\YOUR_USERNAME\AppData\Roaming\Sublime Text 3\Packages\User. It's important to note that the AppData folder is hidden by default, so if you don’t see it, make sure to enable the viewing of hidden files and folders in Windows File Explorer.

docs.title: Step 3: Activate the Configuration
docs.text:
1. Select the Syntax: Once the files are configured, open a file with the .uri extension in Sublime Text. From the bottom-right menu in the editor, select Syntax and then Open all with current extension as... to choose the syntax you just defined.

  2. Test the Configuration: Open a .uri example file and verify that the syntax highlighting and autocomplete work correctly with the example.uri file.

docs.title: Download Files
docs.text:
You can download each of the files needed to configure Sublime Text to work with .uri using the following button:

Download setup files

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: To use .uri in your Fivem server, start by creating a resource with an fxmanifest file. In the files section of the fxmanifest, include your .uri file as you would with any regular file, but make sure to add uri_addon inside this section to indicate that the file is an .uri addon. You can then create your .uri file with any name you like and write the code you want to execute within it. When you're ready to load the content, use the following commands: refresh, followed by buildaddons, and finally ensure uri-core. This process will ensure that your .uri content is properly integrated into your Fivem server.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
1. Fundamentals of the .uri language
  2. Fundamentals of action trees

docs.title: Command Arg Types
docs.text: Name Description achievement An achievement id. any Any type of argument. boolean A boolean, can be true or false. character A character, can be a source, user discord id, user real id, character real id or character NID. clockHours A number between 0 and 23. clockMinutes A number between 0 and 59. clockSeconds A number between 0 and 59. item An item id. npc A NPC id. number A number, can be negative, decimal or integer. Depends in context. permission A permission string. Format: context.action.id. id is optional. Example: Command.tpm permissionGroup A permission group id. positive A positive number. quantity A positive integer number. questData A quest data id. The name of the quest. recipe A recipe id. string A string, can be any text allowing spaces. user A user, can be a source, discord id or real id. vehicle A valid vehicle model name can get from https://docs.fivem.net/docs/game-references/vehicle-models/. weather A valid weather name. Can be CLEAR, OVERCAST, EXTRASUNNY, CLOUDS, CLEARING, RAIN, NEUTRAL, THUNDER, SMOG, FOGGY, SNOWLIGHT, SNOW, BLIZZARD, XMAS. zone A zone id.

docs.title: Config
docs.text: Name Description Edit config The client and server config. data/config/config.json locales The locales used for the translation. data/locales/xx_XX.json onlyserverconfig The server config. data/config/onlyserverconfig.json

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description locale The locale of the server. Example: en_US, es_ES, pt_BR, etc. money An object containing configurations for in-game currency. money.name The name of the in-game currency. Example: Pokédollars. money.symbol The symbol of the currency. Example: $, ¥, etc. money.default The default amount of money players start with. start An object containing configurations for player start. start.fastRestart Enables or disables auto select first character. Only recommended for development. start.position The default spawn coordinates for players selecting/creating character(x, y, z). start.heading The default heading or direction the player will face when selecting/creating character. start.spawns A list of initial spawn points with coordinates and heading. status An object containing configurations for player status. status.tick The time interval in ticks to update hunger and thirst. status.increase.probability The probability of hunger or thirst increasing per tick. status.increase.hunger The amount hunger increases each tick. status.increase.thirst The amount thirst increases each tick. status.damage.probability The probability of the player taking damage due to hunger or thirst. status.damage.hunger The amount of damage dealt when hunger is too low. status.damage.thirst The amount of damage dealt when thirst is too low. dead An object containing configurations for player death. dead.time The time (in ticks or seconds) before the player respawns after death. dead.spawns A list of respawn points with coordinates and heading. dni An object containing DNI (ID) for every character. dni.length The length of the generated DNI (ID). dni.preffix The prefix for the DNI (ID). Example: URI-. weather An object containing weather configurations for the server. weather.defaultTime The default in-game time when the server starts (hours, minutes, seconds). weather.defaultWeather The default weather at the start. Example: CLEAR, RAIN, CLOUDS, etc. weather.timeSpeed The speed at which time progresses in the game. weather.weatherChangeTick The time interval in ticks to check for weather changes. weather.changeWeatherProb The probability of changing the weather at each check. weather.changeStageProb The probability of changing the weather stage within the same type. weather.weatherSet A list of weather sets with their probabilities. Example: CLEAR, RAIN, FOGGY, etc. GPS An object containing GPS locations for the server. GPS.name The identifier of the location for GPS purposes. GPS.label The display name for the GPS location. GPS.coords The coordinates (x, y, z) of the GPS location. nui_logging Enables or disables logging for the NUI interface. debug Enables or disables debugging mode. logging An object containing logging configurations for different modules. logging.saveable Enables or disables saving logs to db. logging.printable Enables or disables printing logs to console. tokens An object containing token mappings for different languages for .uri files.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description localeKey The key is the locale code and the value is the locale name. Use %s for string interpolation. If you want to alternate the order of the arguments, use %s1, %s2, etc. Example: %s1 corresponds to the first argument in the original string.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description version The version of the server shown in loading screen. identifier The identifier got from fivem for the user id, typically 'discord'. discord An object containing configurations for the Discord integration. discord.token The bot token for the Discord API. discord.guild The ID of the Discord server (guild) where the bot operates. discord.announcements The ID of the channel used for sending announcements. This will be shown in the loading screen. discord.roles An object containing role IDs for the a rol name. discord.whitelist_roles Roles that grant whitelist access to the server. discord.queue_roles The queue priority roles from lowest to highest. discord.verified_roles The roles that mark a user as verified. discord.admin_roles Roles that grant full administrative access to the server. restart An object containing configurations for server restarts. restart.times Times at which the server will automatically restart. From lower to higher. Format: HH:MM. restart.script The path to the script used for restarting the server. restart.notify Times (in minutes) to notify players before the server restarts. Example: [1, 5, 15, 30]. logging An object containing logging configurations for different modules. logging.saveable Enables or disables saving logs to db. logging.printable Enables or disables printing logs to console. logging.webhook The webhook URL for sending logs to a Discord channel.

docs.title: Content
docs.text: Name Description Edit achievements Create an achievement. data/content/achievements.json craftingtables Create an craftingtable. data/content/craftingtables.json items Create an item. data/content/items.json permissions Create a permission. data/content/permissions.json recipes Create a recipe for an item. data/content/recipes.json shops Create a shop. data/content/shops.json zones Create a zone using a PolyZone. data/content/zones.json

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description name The achievement name. label The achievement label. description The achievement description. Must contain %s if the achievemnt depends in more than one count. icon The achievement icon. Can be relative within assets folder or an absolute URL. event The event that will trigger the achievement. May require additional parameters depending on the event. count An array of quantities sorted from the lowest to the highest tier. Corresponds to the number of times the event must be triggered to unlock the achievement in its respective tier.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description name The crafting table name used also as label. items An array of recipes that can be crafted in this crafting table.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description name The item name. label The item label. description The item description. icon The item icon. Can be relative within assets folder or an absolute URL. category The item category. It will be used to group items in the inventory. weight The item weight. stackAmount The item maximum stack amount in one slot. isUnique The item is unique then it can't be stacked. isRare The item is rare. isTradeable The item is tradeable between players. isAuctionable The item is auctionable. sellPrice The item sell price. buyPrice The item buy price. isUsable The item is usable. use If the item is usable, the use determines the action when the item is used. Using aditional params that this action may be required. isIllegal The item is illegal. tags The item tags as an array of strings.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description localeKey The key is the locale code and the value is the locale name. Use %s for string interpolation. If you want to alternate the order of the arguments, use %s1, %s2, etc. Example: %s1 corresponds to the first argument in the original string.

From lower to higher. Format: HH:MM. restart.script The path to the script used for restarting the server. restart.notify Times (in minutes) to notify players before the server restarts. Example: [1, 5, 15, 30]. logging An object containing logging configurations for different modules. logging.saveable Enables or disables saving logs to db. logging.printable Enables or disables printing logs to console. logging.webhook The webhook URL for sending logs to a Discord channel.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description context Contextual name of the permission. action Action that the permission allows. name The permission name used as label. description Description of the permission.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description name The recipe name that corresponds to the item name that will be created. requirements The recipe requirements as an array of items with name and quantity. time The recipe crafting time. maxQuantity The recipe maximum quantity that can be crafted.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description name The shop name used also as label. items An array of items that can be bought and sold in this shop. The items must be registered in the items file with its buy and sell prices. If price is 0, the item can't be bought or sold depending on the context.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Description name The zone name. points An array of points that define the zone. Each point is a table with x and y. They come from PolyZone output. options An optional table with minZ, maxZ and debugGrid. utilities An optional table with utilities to give special features to the zone. requirements An optional table with requirements to be inside the zone. Use achievements, quests or items as an array to define the needed requirements. Consider items is an array of objects defining name and quantity for each item.

docs.text: Name Description satiety A positive number that represents the satiety that the item will give to the character. Between 1 and 100.

docs.title: Actions
docs.text: Name Type Description Possibilities forcePokemonBattle behaviour Forces a Pokémon battle between the NPC and a nearby player within a reasonable radius and who has not lost against him. The battle is initiated without the player's consent. 2 givePokemon interaction Gives a pokemon copy choosed by an ID to the character. 2 hasFoughtPokemonBattle interaction Checks if the character has previously fought against the NPC's trainer. 2 hasLostPokemonBattle interaction Checks if the NPC's Pokémon trainer has lost a battle against the character's Pokémon trainer. 2 hasPokemonLike interaction Checks if the character's trainer has a certain number of Pokémon that match the specified criteria. Use '_' for any parameter you do not want to specify. 2 hasTiedPokemonBattle interaction Checks if the NPC's Pokémon trainer has tied a battle against the character's Pokémon trainer. 2 hasWonPokemonBattle interaction Checks if the NPC's Pokémon trainer has won a battle against the character's Pokémon trainer. 2 startPokemonBattle interaction Initiates a Pokémon battle between the character's trainer and an NPC. The result of the battle can be a win, loss, tie, or an forced stop. 4

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Forces a Pokémon battle between the NPC and a nearby player within a reasonable radius and who has not lost against him. The battle is initiated without the player's consent.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: # Name Type Mandatory Description Multiple 1 actives integer No The number of active Pokémon in the battle. For example, 2 would be a 2v2 battle. No 2 NPC NPCID No Additional NPC in rival team. Yes

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: # Description 1 The battle was successfully forced or running. 2 The battle could not be forced or not running.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
POKEMON 

  id example_pokemon_id 
  name bulbasaur 
  level 5 
  moves vine_whip 

  TRAINER 

  npc AggressiveTrainer 
  pokemon example_pokemon_id 

  NPC 

  name AggressiveTrainer 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_01 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    nothing 

  behaviour 
    forcePokemonBattle

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Gives a pokemon copy choosed by an ID to the character.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: # Name Type Mandatory Description Multiple 1 pokemonId PokemonID Yes The ID of the pokemon to copy and give. No

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: # Description 1 The pokemon was given successfully. 2 The pokemon couldn't be given.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
POKEMON 

  id pokemon_id_example 
  name charmander 
  level 5 
  moves tackle 

  NPC 

  name NPC 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_01 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    localCheck given_pokemon 
      tell "hello, i will give you a charmander" 
        givePokemon pokemon_id_example 
      tell "I gave you a charmander previously..." 

  behaviour 
    nothing

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Checks if the character has previously fought against the NPC's trainer.

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: # Description 1 The character has fought against the NPC's trainer. 2 The character has not fought against the NPC's trainer.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
POKEMON 

  id example_pokemon_id 
  name bulbasaur 
  level 5 
  moves vine_whip 

  TRAINER 

  npc example_trainer_id 
  pokemon example_pokemon_id 

  NPC 

  name example_trainer_id 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_01 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    hasFoughtPokemonBattle 
      tell "You have already battled with me before!" 
      tell "We haven't battled yet. Prepare yourself!" 
        startPokemonBattle 

  behaviour 
    nothing

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Checks if the NPC's Pokémon trainer has lost a battle against the character's Pokémon trainer.

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: # Description 1 The NPC's trainer has been defeated by the character's trainer. 2 The NPC's trainer has not been defeated by the character's trainer.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
POKEMON 

  id example_pokemon_id 
  name bulbasaur 
  level 5 
  moves vine_whip 

  TRAINER 

  npc Rival 
  pokemon example_pokemon_id 

  NPC 

  name Rival

  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Checks if the character's trainer has a certain number of Pokémon that match the specified criteria. Use '_' for any parameter you do not want to specify.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: # Name Type Mandatory Description Multiple 1 quantity integer Yes The number of Pokémon that must match the criteria. No 2 species PokemonSpeciesID No Specifies the species of the Pokémon. Accepts any valid Pokémon species name or '_'. No 3 minLevel integer No Specifies the minimum level of the Pokémon. Accepts any positive integer representing a Pokémon level or '_'. No 4 maxLevel integer No Specifies the maximum level of the Pokémon. Accepts any positive integer representing a Pokémon level or '_'. No 5 ptype PokemonTypeID No Specifies the type of the Pokémon. Accepts any valid Pokémon type (e.g., 'Fire', 'Water') or '_'. No 6 sex string No Specifies the sex of the Pokémon. Accepts 'M' for Male, 'F' for Female, 'N' for neutral, or '_'. No 7 shiny boolean No Indicates if the Pokémon must be shiny. Accepts 'true', 'false', or '_'. No 8 item ItemID No Specifies the item the Pokémon must have equipped. Accepts any valid item name or '_'. No 9 nature PokemonNatureID No Specifies the nature of the Pokémon. Accepts any valid Pokémon nature or '_'. No 10 ability PokemonAbilityID No Specifies the ability the Pokémon must have. Accepts any valid Pokémon ability or '_'. No 11 move1 PokemonMoveID No Specifies the first move the Pokémon must know. Accepts any valid Pokémon move name or '_'. No 12 move2 PokemonMoveID No Specifies the second move the Pokémon must know. Accepts any valid Pokémon move name or '_'. No 13 move3 PokemonMoveID No Specifies the third move the Pokémon must know. Accepts any valid Pokémon move name or '_'. No 14 move4 PokemonMoveID No Specifies the fourth move the Pokémon must know. Accepts any valid Pokémon move name or '_'. No 15 IV_HP_min integer No Specifies the minimum IV for the HP stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 16 IV_HP_max integer No Specifies the maximum IV for the HP stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 17 IV_ATK_min integer No Specifies the minimum IV for the Attack stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 18 IV_ATK_max integer No Specifies the maximum IV for the Attack stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 19 IV_DEF_min integer No Specifies the minimum IV for the Defense stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 20 IV_DEF_max integer No Specifies the maximum IV for the Defense stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 21 IV_SPA_min integer No Specifies the minimum IV for the Special Attack stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 22 IV_SPA_max integer No Specifies the maximum IV for the Special Attack stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 23 IV_SPD_min integer No Specifies the minimum IV for the Special Defense stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 24 IV_SPD_max integer No Specifies the maximum IV for the Special Defense stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 25 IV_SPE_min integer No Specifies the minimum IV for the Speed stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 26 IV_SPE_max integer No Specifies the maximum IV for the Speed stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 31 or '_'. No 27 EV_HP_min integer No Specifies the minimum EV for the HP stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 28 EV_HP_max integer No Specifies the maximum EV for the HP stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 29 EV_ATK_min integer No Specifies the minimum EV for the Attack stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 30 EV_ATK_max integer No Specifies the maximum EV for the Attack stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 31 EV_DEF_min integer No Specifies the minimum EV for the Defense stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 32 EV_DEF_max integer No Specifies the maximum EV for the Defense stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 33 EV_SPA_min integer No Specifies the minimum EV for the Special Attack stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 34 EV_SPA_max integer No Specifies the maximum EV for the Special Attack stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 35 EV_SPD_min integer No Specifies the minimum EV for the Special Defense stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 36 EV_SPD_max integer No Specifies the maximum EV for the Special Defense stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 37 EV_SPE_min integer No Specifies the minimum EV for the Speed stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No 38 EV_SPE_max integer No Specifies the maximum EV for the Speed stat. Accepts any integer between 0 and 252 or '_'. No

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: # Description 1 The character's trainer has the required Pokémon. 2 The character's trainer does not have the required Pokémon.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
NPC 

  name Rival 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_02 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    tell "Checking if you have a Pokémon like this..." 
      hasPokemonLike 1 pikachu 10 _ _ M _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
        tell "You have a Pokémon like this." 
        tell "You don't have a Pokémon like this." 

  behaviour 
    nothing

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Checks if the NPC's Pokémon trainer has tied a battle against the character's Pokémon trainer.

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: # Description 1 The NPC's trainer has tied with the character's trainer. 2 The NPC's trainer has not tied with the character's trainer.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
POKEMON 

  id example_pokemon_id 
  name bulbasaur 
  level 5 
  moves vine_whip 

  TRAINER 

  npc Rival 
  pokemon example_pokemon_id 

  NPC 

  name Rival 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_02 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    hasTiedPokemonBattle 
      tell "Our battle ended in a tie!" 
      tell "Our battle did not end in a tie!" 

  behaviour 
    nothing

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Checks if the NPC's Pokémon trainer has won a battle against the character's Pokémon trainer.

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: # Description 1 The NPC's trainer has defeated the character's trainer. 2 The NPC's trainer has not defeated the character's trainer.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
POKEMON 

  id example_pokemon_id 
  name bulbasaur 
  level 5 
  moves vine_whip 

  TRAINER 

  npc Rival 
  pokemon example_pokemon_id 

  NPC 

  name Rival 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_02 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    hasWonPokemonBattle 
      tell "You have been defeated by my Pokémon!" 
      tell "You still stand undefeated!" 

  behaviour 
    nothing

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Initiates a Pokémon battle between the character's trainer and an NPC. The result of the battle can be a win, loss, tie, or an forced stop.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: # Name Type Mandatory Description Multiple 1 actives integer No The number of active Pokémon in the battle. For example, 2 would be a 2v2 battle. No 2 NPC NPCID No Additional NPC in rival team. Yes

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text: # Description 1 The character's trainer won the battle. 2 The character's trainer lost the battle. 3 The battle ended in a tie. 4 An error occurred during the battle initiation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
POKEMON 

  id example_pokemon_id 
  name bulbasaur 
  level 5 
  moves vine_whip 

  TRAINER 

  npc Rival 
  pokemon example_pokemon_id 

  NPC 

  name Rival 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_02 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    startPokemonBattle 2 
      tell "Congratulations, you won!" 
      tell "You lost the battle." 
      tell "It's a tie!" 
      tell "Something went wrong during the battle." 

  behaviour 
    nothing

docs.title: Command Arg Types
docs.text: Name Description EV Gets a pokemon EV by value (0-255). IV Gets a pokemon IV by value (0-31). ability Gets a pokemon ability by name. ailment Gets a pokemon ailment by name. battle Gets a pokemon battle by real id, increment id, trainer or pokemon selector. move Gets a pokemon move by name. nature Gets a pokemon nature by name. pokeball Gets a pokemon pokeball by name. pokemon A pokemon id. pokemonData A pokemon valid species name. pokemonSelector Use global-(id) to get a pokemon by id, pool-(id) to get a pokemon in pool, spawned-(id) to get a spawned pokemon by networkId, (trainer)-(pokemonInTeam) to get a pokemon in a trainer's team or (trainer)-(box)-(pokemonInBox) to get a pokemon in a trainer's box. Examples: global-test -> Get pokemon with ID test, pool-1 -> Get first pokemon in pool, spawned-65535 -> Gets spawned pokemon using networkid, me-1-1 -> Gets pokemon 1 in box 1 of yourself, 1-2 -> Gets pokemon 2 in team of trainer identified as 1. pokemonSpawned A valid networkid of a spawned pokemon. pokemonTeam The number of the pokemon in your team (1-6). poolPokemon A valid id in pokemon pool. skin Gets a pokemon skin by name. trainer Gets a trainer as a character is got.

POKEMON 

  id pokemon_id_example 
  name charmander 
  level 5 
  moves tackle 

  NPC 

  name NPC 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_01 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    givePokemon pokemon_id_example 

  behaviour 
    nothing

docs.title: Attribute pokemon
docs.text: Name Required Description Parameters pokemon Yes The team of Pokémon that the trainer will have. 1

docs.title: Parameters of pokemon
docs.text: # Name Type Description Multiple 1 Pokemon PokemonID The Pokémon ID that the trainer will have. Yes

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
POKEMON 

  id trainer_pokemon_id 
  name bulbasaur 
  level 5 
  moves vine_whip 

  TRAINER 

  npc Rival 
  pokemon trainer_pokemon_id 

  NPC 

  name Rival 
  model a_m_m_eastsa_02 
  position -1020.72 4839.78 258.30 0.0 

  interaction 
    startPokemonBattle 

  behaviour 
    nothing

docs.title: Events
docs.text: Name Description pokemonBattleStopped Triggered when a Pokémon battle stops. The event can track whether the player's trainer has won or lost, and optionally if the battle was against a specific NPC. pokemonCaptured Triggers when a Pokémon is captured by a trainer. The achievement validates specific characteristics of the Pokémon before incrementing the counter. pokemonCapturedRegistered Triggered when a Pokémon species is registered as captured in the trainer's Pokédex. The count is incremented by 1 each time a Pokémon of the specified species is captured and registered. pokemonFainted Triggered when a Pokémon faints during a battle. The achievement validates various conditions such as whether the Pokémon is wild, owned by the player, and specific characteristics of the Pokémon and the player's team before incrementing the count. pokemonSeenRegistered Triggered when a Pokémon species is registered as seen in the trainer's Pokédex. The count is incremented by 1 each time a Pokémon of the specified species is seen and registered. teamFainted Triggered when the entire team of the player's trainer faints in a Pokémon battle. The count is incremented by 1 each time this event occurs. teamHealed Triggered when the entire team of the player's trainer is fully healed. The count is incremented by 1 each time this event occurs.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggered when a Pokémon battle stops. The event can track whether the player's trainer has won or lost, and optionally if the battle was against a specific NPC.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Mandatory Description state BattleState Yes The state of the battle, either 'win' or 'lose'. This determines if the achievement is triggered based on the outcome for the player's trainer. againstNPC NPCID No The identifier of the NPC the trainer is battling against. If specified, the achievement is only triggered if this NPC is involved in the battle.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggers when a Pokémon is captured by a trainer. The achievement validates specific characteristics of the Pokémon before incrementing the counter.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Mandatory Description species PokemonSpeciesID No Specifies the species of the Pokémon that must be captured to trigger the achievement. Accepts any valid Pokémon species name. notSpecies PokemonSpeciesID No Specifies a species that must not be the species of the captured Pokémon for the achievement to count. Accepts any valid Pokémon species name. minLevel integer No Specifies the minimum level the Pokémon must have to trigger the achievement. Accepts any positive integer representing a Pokémon level. maxLevel integer No Specifies the maximum level the Pokémon can have to trigger the achievement. Accepts any positive integer representing a Pokémon level. notMinLevel integer No Specifies the minimum level the Pokémon must not have to trigger the achievement. Accepts any positive integer representing a Pokémon level. notMaxLevel integer No Specifies the maximum level the Pokémon must not have to trigger the achievement. Accepts any positive integer representing a Pokémon level. type PokemonTypeID No Specifies the type of the Pokémon that must be captured to trigger the achievement. Accepts any valid Pokémon type (e.g., 'fire', 'water'). notType PokemonTypeID No Specifies a type that must not be the type of the captured Pokémon for the achievement to count. Accepts any valid Pokémon type. sex string No Specifies the sex of the Pokémon that must be captured. Accepts 'M' for Male, 'F' for Female, and 'N' for neutral. notSex string No Specifies a sex that the captured Pokémon must not have. docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggered when a Pokémon species is registered as captured in the trainer's Pokédex. The count is incremented by 1 each time a Pokémon of the specified species is captured and registered.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Mandatory Description species PokemonSpecies No The species of the Pokémon being registered as captured. If not specified, any species will trigger the event.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggered when a Pokémon faints during a battle. The achievement validates various conditions such as whether the Pokémon is wild, owned by the player, and specific characteristics of the Pokémon and the player's team before incrementing the count.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Mandatory Description wild boolean No Indicates if the fainted Pokémon must be wild for the achievement to count. Accepts 'true' or 'false'. If 'true', only wild Pokémon trigger the achievement. owned boolean No Indicates if the fainted Pokémon must be owned by the player's trainer for the achievement to count. Accepts 'true' or 'false'. If 'true', only Pokémon owned by the player trigger the achievement. count integer No Specifies the number of Pokémon in team that must meet the team conditions to trigger the achievement. Accepts any positive integer not more than 6. species PokemonSpeciesID No Specifies the species of the Pokémon that must faint to trigger the achievement. Accepts any valid Pokémon species name. notSpecies PokemonSpeciesID No Specifies a species that must not be the species of the fainted Pokémon for the achievement to count. Accepts any valid Pokémon species name. minLevel integer No Specifies the minimum level the Pokémon must have to trigger the achievement. Accepts any positive integer representing a Pokémon level. maxLevel integer No Specifies the maximum level the Pokémon can have to trigger the achievement. docs.title: Example
docs.text: pokemonFainted 1 wild=true owned=false species=Charizard teamSpecies=Charizard count=3

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggered when a Pokémon species is registered as seen in the trainer's Pokédex. The count is incremented by 1 each time a Pokémon of the specified species is seen and registered.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Mandatory Description species PokemonSpecies No The species of the Pokémon being registered as seen. If not specified, any species will trigger the event.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggered when the entire team of the player's trainer faints in a Pokémon battle. The count is incremented by 1 each time this event occurs.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggered when the entire team of the player's trainer is fully healed. The count is incremented by 1 each time this event occurs.

docs.title: Item Use
docs.text: Name Description escapeRope Use the item as an escape rope in zones with this feature. pokeball Use the item as a pokeball. Must be defined in pokeball config file. potion Use the item as a potion. repellent Use the item as a repellent.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Use the item as an escape rope in zones with this feature.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Use the item as a pokeball. Must be defined in pokeball config file.

docs.title: Params

docs.title: Params

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Powers up moves of the same type as the Pokémon.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Eevee No 2

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Normal-type moves become Flying-type moves. The power of those moves is boosted a little.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Damages the attacker if it knocks out the Pokémon with a move that makes direct contact.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Voltorb No 3 Electrode No 3

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Boosts the power of the Pokémon's move if it is the last to act that turn.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Magnemite No 3 Magneton No 3 Staryu No 3 Starmie No 3 Porygon No 3 Porygon2 No 3

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The Pokémon is angered when it takes a critical hit, and that maxes its Attack stat.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Mankey No 2 Primeape No 2 Tauros No 2

docs.title: Description
docs.text: When an attack causes its HP to drop to half or less, the Pokémon gets angry. This lowers its Defense and Sp. Def stats but boosts its Attack, Sp. Atk, and Speed stats.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The Pokémon can sense an opposing Pokémon's dangerous moves.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Eevee No 3

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Prevents opposing Pokémon from fleeing from battle.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Diglett No 2 Dugtrio No 2

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The mysterious tail covering the Pokémon's head makes opponents unable to use priority moves against the Pokémon or its allies.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Protects the Pokémon and its allies from effects that prevent the use of moves.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This Ability combines the effects of both Calyrex's Unnerve Ability and Glastrier's Chilling Neigh Ability.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This Ability combines the effects of both Calyrex's Unnerve Ability and Spectrier's Grim Neigh Ability.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The effects of “Aura” Abilities are reversed to lower the power of affected moves.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: If the Pokémon is not holding an item, it will fetch the Poké Ball from the first failed throw of the battle.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Hard armor protects the Pokémon from critical hits.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Cubone No 3 Marowak No 3 Kabuto No 2 Kabutops No 2

docs.title: Description
docs.text: When the Pokémon knocks out a target, its bond with its Trainer is strengthened, and its Attack, Sp. Atk, and Speed stats are boosted.

docs.title: Basic information
docs.text: ID Name beads-of-ruin Beads of Ruin

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The power of the Pokémon's ruinous beads lowers the Sp. Def stats of all Pokémon except itself.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The Pokémon boosts its most proficient stat each time it knocks out a Pokémon.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Boosts the Pokémon's Sp. Atk stat when it takes a hit that causes its HP to drop to half or less.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Prevents the Pokémon from having its Defense stat lowered.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Pidgey No 3 Pidgeotto No 3 Pidgeot No 3

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Powers up Fire-type moves when the Pokémon's HP is low.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Protects the Pokémon from ball and bomb moves.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The Pokémon's HP is restored when it eats any Berry, in addition to the Berry's usual effect.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: When the Pokémon knocks out a target, it utters a chilling neigh, which boosts its Attack stat.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Boosts the Pokémon's Speed stat in harsh sunlight.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Prevents other Pokémon's moves or Abilities from lowering the Pokémon's stats.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Psyduck No 2 Golduck No 2 Lickitung No 3

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The Pokémon’s type becomes the type of the move used on it.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The Pokémon is always drowsing and will never wake up. It can attack while in its sleeping state.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: When the Pokémon enters a battle, it goes inside the mouth of an ally Dondozo if one is on the field. The Pokémon then issues commands from there.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Boosts the Pokémon's Sp. Atk stat sharply when its stats are lowered by an opposing Pokémon.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Jigglypuff No 2 Wigglytuff No 2 Igglybuff No 2

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The Pokémon's compound eyes boost its accuracy.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Butterfree No 1 Venonat No 1 Yanma No 2

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Reverses any stat changes affecting the Pokémon so that attempts to boost its stats instead lower them—and attempts to lower its stats will boost them.

docs.title: Pokemon with this ability
docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Shuckle No 3

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The Pokémon can poison the target even if it's a Steel or Poison type.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: When the Pokémon enters a battle, it copies an ally's stat changes.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: When the Pokémon is hit by an attack, it scatters cotton fluff around and lowers the Speed stat of all Pokémon except itself.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: When the Pokémon eats a Berry, it will regurgitate that Berry at the end of the next turn and eat it one more time.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: When the Pokémon enters a battle, it scatters medicine from its shell, which removes all stat changes from allies.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: May disable a move that has dealt damage to the Pokémon.

docs.text: Icon Pokémon Hidden Ability Slot Gengar No 1

docs.title: Description

docs.title: Description

docs.title: Description

docs.title: Description

docs.title: Items
docs.text: ID Name Icon Category Description HM01 Corte HM Una máquina técnica que permite a un Pokémon aprender el movimiento Corte, que se puede usar para cortar ciertos obstáculos fuera de combate. aguav_berry Baya Guaya berries Una baya que puede restaurar la salud del Pokémon que la lleva cuando su HP baja a la mitad o menos. No obstante, puede causar confusión si al Pokémon no le gusta su sabor. amber_pickaxe Pico Ámbar item Un trozo de ámbar que contiene los genes de un Pokémon antiguo. Se dice que puede usarse para revivir a Aerodactyl. amulet_coin Moneda Amuleto special_items Un amuleto que aumenta la cantidad de dinero que se gana después de una batalla exitosa cuando se lleva equipado en un Pokémon. Los entrenadores de Pokémon a veces equipan a sus Pokémon con este amuleto para aumentar sus ganancias económicas tras los combates. antidote Antídoto status_healing_items Un objeto que cura el envenenamiento de un Pokémon. apicot_berry Baya Aricoc berries Una baya que, cuando es consumida por un Pokémon, restaura su salud, pero puede confundir a aquellos que detestan el sabor amargo. aspear_berry Baya Perasi berries Una Baya que se utiliza para hacer Pokochow. Si un Pokémon la lleva equipada, se liberará de la confusión. attract Atracción TMs Si el objetivo es del género opuesto, se enamora del usuario y tiene una probabilidad del 50% de no atacar. awakening Despertar status_healing_items Un spray que despierta a un Pokémon dormido. babiri_berry Baya Baribá berries Una baya que, cuando es llevada por un Pokémon, reduce el daño de un ataque de tipo acero que recibe. belue_berry Baya Andano berries Una baya común que a menudo se utiliza en la preparación de Pokochos. berry_juice Zumo de Baya healing_items Un jugo refrescante exprimido de bayas. Al consumirlo, restaura 20 PS del Pokémon. berserk_gene Gen Loco held_items Un gen extraño y misterioso que se ha vuelto inestable. Su uso es desconocido, y algunos creen que puede tener efectos inesperados en los Pokémon. big_pearl Perla Grande sellable_items Una perla de gran tamaño que se puede vender a un precio aún mayor en tiendas. bigmushroom Seta Grande sellable_items Una seta de gran tamaño que se encuentra en áreas boscosas y húmedas. Las setas grandes son conocidas por su valor culinario y sus propiedades medicinales en el mundo de los Pokémon. Algunos entrenadores de Pokémon las buscan para utilizarlas en pociones y preparaciones especiales. Sin embargo, la recolección de setas grandes está regulada en muchas regiones debido a su importancia ecológica. bitter_dry_poffin Pokocho Amarseco utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho amargo y seco que desafía los sentidos de entrenadores valientes. bitter_poffin Pokocho Amargo utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho amargo que desafía los sentidos de entrenadores valientes. bitter_sour_poffin Pokocho Amarácido utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho amargo con un toque ácido que desafía los sentidos de entrenadores valientes. bitter_spicy_poffin Pokocho Amarpicante utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho amargo con un toque picante que desafía los sentidos de entrenadores valientes. bitter_sweet_poffin Pokocho Amardulce utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho amargo con un toque dulce que desafía los sentidos de entrenadores valientes. black_apricorn Bonguri Negro apricorns Una pequeña fruta que se puede convertir en una Poké Ball. black_belt Cinturón Negro held_items Un cinturón negro que simboliza un alto nivel de habilidad en las artes marciales. Cuando se lleva equipado por un Pokémon, aumenta la potencia de sus movimientos de tipo Lucha en batalla. Es un objeto muy valorado por los entrenadores que se especializan en Pokémon de tipo Lucha. black_glasses Gafas de Sol held_items Un par de elegantes gafas de sol que no solo protegen los ojos de su portador de la luz solar intensa, sino que también aumentan la potencia de los movimientos de tipo Siniestro de un Pokémon cuando se llevan equipadas. Estas gafas son muy populares entre los entrenadores de Pokémon de tipo Siniestro. blizzard Ventisca TMs Un poderoso movimiento de tipo Hielo que también puede dejar al objetivo congelado. blue_apricorn Bonguri Azul apricorns Una pequeña fruta que se puede convertir en una Poké Ball. blue_pokeblock Pokecubo Azul utility_pokemon_items Un pequeño cubo azul que contiene un regalo misterioso para tu Pokémon. blue_pokeblock+ Pokecubo Azul Plus utility_pokemon_items Un Pokecubo Azul con un extra especial para tu Pokémon. bluk_berry Baya Oram berries Una baya que, cuando es consumida, restaura 10 puntos de salud al Pokémon. brick_piece Ladrillo miscellaneous_items Un pequeño fragmento de ladrillo que a menudo se utiliza en construcciones. Este fragmento en particular parece tener un valor histórico o artístico, lo que lo hace más valioso para coleccionistas y estudiosos. Aunque no es muy común, los entrenadores de Pokémon a veces lo encuentran mientras exploran ruinas o sitios de construcción antiguos. bright_powder Polvo Brillo item Un polvo brillante y misterioso que es capaz de hacer que un Pokémon brille de forma especial. burn_heal Antiquemar status_healing_items Un spray que cura la quemadura de un Pokémon. calcium Calcio stat_increase Un nutritivo suplemento de vitaminas. Aumenta el Ataque Especial base de un Pokémon. carbos Carburante stat_increase Un nutritivo suplemento de vitaminas. Aumenta la Velocidad base de un Pokémon. cave_map Mapa cueva utility_items Un mapa de la cueva que muestra cómo navegar por ella. charcoal Carbon held_items Un pedazo de carbón de alta calidad que aumenta la potencia de los movimientos de tipo Fuego de un Pokémon cuando se lleva equipado. Los entrenadores de Pokémon a menudo lo utilizan para potenciar los ataques de sus Pokémon de tipo Fuego en batalla. charti_berry Baya Alcho berries Una baya que, cuando es llevada por un Pokémon, debilita la potencia de un ataque de tipo lucha dirigido hacia él. cheri_berry Baya Zreza berries Una Baya que se utiliza para hacer Pokochow. Si se utiliza en un Pokémon, sufriendo una alteración de las características, estos aumentarán. chesto_berry Baya Atania berries Una Baya que se utiliza para hacer Pokochow. Si un Pokémon la lleva equipada, se curará automáticamente de la congelación. chilan_berry Baya Chilan berries Una baya que, cuando es llevada por un Pokémon, reduce el daño de un ataque normal que recibe. chople_berry Baya Pomaro berries Una baya que, cuando es sostenida por un Pokémon, debilita el daño de un ataque súper efectivo de tipo Fuego que lo afecta. cleanse_tag Amuleto special_items Un amuleto que funciona como un repelente. clear_bell Campana Clara miscellaneous_items Una campana mágica que emite un sonido claro y puro. Se cree que esta campana es un objeto sagrado relacionado con los Pokémon legendarios Ho-Oh y Lugia. Su tintineo tiene el poder de purificar el espíritu y atraer a Pokémon de gran pureza. Los entrenadores valoran mucho esta campana por su conexión con las leyendas de Pokémon. coba_berry Baya Kouba berries Una baya que, cuando es llevada por un Pokémon, debilita la potencia de un ataque de tipo volador dirigido hacia él. colbur_berry Baya Dillo berries Una baya que, cuando es llevada por un Pokémon, aumenta su Defensa tras recibir un ataque físico. cornn_berry Baya Maíz berries Una baya rara que se suele usar para hacer Pokochos. Tiene un sabor peculiar que a algunos Pokémon les encanta. curse Maldición TM Una máquina técnica que permite a un Pokémon aprender el movimiento Maldición. Este movimiento tiene un efecto variante dependiendo del tipo del Pokémon que lo use. custap_berry Baya Chiri berries Una baya que, cuando es consumida por un Pokémon, cura la parálisis. defense_curl Rizo Defensa TMs El usuario se enrolla para ocultar su punto débil. Sube la Defensa del usuario. destiny_knot Lazo Destino held_items Un misterioso lazo que une los destinos de dos Pokémon en combate, causando un efecto en el oponente cuando uno de ellos es derrotado. detect Detección TMs Permite esquivar todos los ataques que vayan a alcanzar al usuario durante el turno en que se utiliza, incluyendo los movimientos que cuentan con un objetivo fijo. dig Excavar TMs Un movimiento de tipo Tierra en el que el Pokémon se sumerge bajo tierra en el primer turno, esquivando la mayoría de los ataques, y luego emerge para golpear en el segundo turno. dire_hit Directo battle_boost Un objeto que se utiliza durante la batalla. Aumenta la precisión de un Pokémon solo en esa batalla. dome_fossil Fósil Domo item Un fósil de un Pokémon que vivió hace mucho tiempo. Se dice que se puede usar para revivir a Kabuto. dome_pickaxe Pico Domo item Un fósil de un Pokémon prehistórico. Se dice que puede usarse para revivir a Kabuto. double_team Doble equipo TMs Un movimiento que permite al usuario incrementar su evasión, haciéndolo más escurridizo y difícil de alcanzar por los ataques enemigos. dragon_breath Dragoaliento TMs Un movimiento de tipo Dragón que no solo inflige daño, sino que también tiene una posibilidad de paralizar al oponente. dragon_fang Colmillo Dragón held_items Un afilado colmillo de dragón que aumenta la potencia de los movimientos de tipo Dragón de un Pokémon cuando se lleva equipado. Los entrenadores de Pokémon a menudo lo utilizan para potenciar los ataques de sus Pokémon de tipo Dragón en batalla. dragon_scale Escamadragón evolutionary_items Una escama brillante y escamosa que a menudo se dice que es el resultado de la evolución de ciertos Pokémon. Puede ser utilizada para inducir una evolución especial en ciertos Pokémon cuando se intercambia. Los entrenadores de Pokémon valoran mucho esta escama por su rareza y sus propiedades evolutivas únicas. dream_eater Come Sueños TMs El usuario se come los sueños del objetivo dormido. El daño del movimiento se suma a los PS del usuario igual ala mitad del daño causado al objetivo. dry_bitter_poffin Pokocho Secoamargo utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho seco y amargo que desafía los paladares de entrenadores valientes y sus Pokémon. dry_poffin Pokocho Seco utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho seco que satisface el paladar de los entrenadores y Pokémon. dry_sour_poffin Pokocho Secoácido utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho seco y ácido que desafía los paladares de entrenadores valientes y sus Pokémon. dry_spicy_poffin Pokocho Secopicante utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho seco y picante que desafía los sentidos de los entrenadores valientes. dry_sweet_poffin Pokocho Secodulce utility_pokemon_items Un Pokocho seco y dulce que deleita los paladares de entrenadores y Pokémon por igual. durin_berry Baya Rudion berries Una baya que aumenta la probabilidad de atrapar Pokémon cuando se utiliza antes de lanzar una Poké Ball.
